Quantum mechanics vs local realism is that the question Emilio Santos Depart men to de Fi sica Universidad de Cantabria Santander Spain July Abstract The conjecture is made that quantum mechanics is compatible with local hidden variables or local realism The conjecture seems to be ruled out by the theoretical argument of Bell but it is supported by the empirical fact that nobody has been able to perform loophole free test of local realism in spite of renewed ort during almost years During the last three decades many experiments have been performed aimed at ruling out any local hidden variables LH theory In spite of the ort some dec ien cie in the proof remain the most important being described by locality and detector ec ien cy loopholes According to recent reports the two loopholes have been closed However each loophole has been closed in die rent experiment That this is not enough to refute all LH theories has been pointed out by aid man agree with that paper except for point which will be commented below Therefore shall not spent time in repeating the arguments which may be summarized as follows The existence of loophole means that quantum mechanics and LH are actually compatible for the experiment and therefore the experiment is unable to discriminate between quantum mechanics and LH theories The fact that quantum predictions are ve ried certainly reinforces our belief in the correctness of quantum theory But the experiment says nothing against LH theories

Economic Models for Management of Resources in Grid Computing Rajkumar Buy ya Heinz Stocking er Jonathan Giddy and David Abrams on CRC for Enterprise Distributed Systems Technology CERN European Organization for Nuclear Research School of Computer Science and Software Engineering CMS Experiment Computing Group Database Section Monash University Melbourne Australia CH Geneva Switzerland Email rajkumar jon david css monash edu au Heinz Stocking er cern ch Abstract The accelerated development in Grid and peer to peer computing has positioned them as promising next generation computing platforms They enable the creation of Virtual Enterprises VE for sharing resources distributed across the world However resource management application development and usage models in these environments is complex undertaking This is due to the geographic distribution of resources that are owned by different organizations The resource owners of each of these resources have different usage or access policies and cost models and varying loads and availability In order to address complex resource management issues we have proposed computational economy framework for resource allocation and for regulating supply and demand in Grid computing environments The framework provides mechanisms for optimizing resource provider and consumer objective functions through trading and brokering services In real world market there exist various economic models for setting the price for goods based on supply and demand and their value to the user They include commodity market posted price tenders and auctions In this paper we discuss the use of these models for interaction between Grid components in deciding resource value and the necessary infrastructure to realize them In addition to normal services offered by Grid computing systems we need an infrastructure to support interaction protocols allocation mechanisms currency secure banking and enforcement services Furthermore we demonstrate the usage of some of these economic models in resource brokering through Nimrod deadline and cost based scheduling for two different optimization strategies on the World Wide Grid WW test bed that contains resources located on five continents Asia Australia Europe North America and South America

Computational Economy for Grid Computing and its Implementation in the Nimrod Resource Broker David Abrams on Rajkumar Buy ya and Jonathan Giddy School of Computer Science and Software Engineering CRC for Distributed Systems Technology Monash University Caulfield Campus Monash University Caulfield Campus Melbourne Australia Melbourne Australia Email david rajkumar jon css monash edu au Abstract Computational Grids coupling geographically distributed resources such as PCs workstations clusters and scientific instruments have emerged as next generation computing platform for solving large scale problems in science engineering and commerce However application development resource management and scheduling in these environments continue to be complex undertaking In this article we discuss our efforts in developing resource management system for scheduling computations on resources distributed across the world with varying quality of service Our service oriented grid computing system called Nimrod manages all operations associated with remote execution including resource discovery trading scheduling based on economic principles and user defined quality of service requirement The Nimrod resource broker is implemented by leveraging existing technologies such as Globus and provides new services that are essential for constructing industrial strength Grids We discuss results of preliminary experiments on scheduling some parametric computations using the Nimrod resource broker on world wide grid test bed that spans five continents

Grid Sim Toolkit for the Modeling and Simulation of Distributed Resource Management and Scheduling for Grid Computing Rajkumar Buy ya and Man zur Mur shed School of Computer Science and Software Eng Gippsland School of Computing and IT Monash University Caulfield Campus Monash University Gippsland Campus Melbourne Vic Australia Churchill Vic Australia rajkumar buy ya com Man zur Mur shed info tech monash edu au Abstract Clusters grids and peer to peer networks have emerged as popular paradigms for next generation parallel and distributed computing They enable aggregation of distributed resources for solving large scale problems in science engineering and commerce In grid and computing environments the resources are usually geographically distributed in multiple administrative domains managed and owned by different organizations with different policies and interconnected by wide area networks or the Internet This introduces number of resource management and application scheduling challenges in the domain of security resource and policy heterogeneity fault tolerance continuously changing resource conditions and policies The resource management and scheduling systems for grid computing need to manage resources and application execution depending on either resource consumers or owners requirements and continuously adapt to changes in resource availability The management of resources and scheduling of applications in such large scale distributed systems is complex undertaking In order to prove the effectiveness of resource brokers and associated scheduling algorithms their performance needs to be evaluated under different scenarios such as varying number of resources and users with different requirements In grid environment it is hard and even impossible to perform scheduler performance evaluation in repeatable and controllable manner as resources and users are distributed across multiple organizations with their own policies To overcome this limitation we have developed Java based discrete event grid simulation toolkit called Grid Sim The toolkit supports modeling and simulation of heterogeneous grid resources both time and space shared users and application models It provides primitives for creation of application tasks mapping of tasks to resources and their management To demonstrate suitability of the Grid Sim toolkit we have simulated Nimrod like grid resource broker and evaluated the performance of deadline and budget constrained cost and time minimization scheduling algorithms

Case for Renewed Activity in the Giant Radio Galaxy Lakshmi Sari pall Ravi Sub rahman yan Australia Telescope National Facility CSIRO Locked bag arra bri NSW Australia and Uday Shankar Raman Research Institute Sada shiva nagar Bangalore India ABSTRACT We present AT CA radio observations of the giant radio galaxy at and cm wavelengths in total intensity and polarization The images clearly reveal bright inner double structure within more extended edge brightened lobe emission The lack of hotspots at the ends of the outer lobes the strong core and the inner double structure with its edge brightened morphology lead us to suggest that this giant radio galaxy is undergoing renewed nuclear activity appears to be striking example of radio galaxy where young double source is evolving within older lobe material We also report the detection of Mpc long linear feature which is oriented perpendicular to the radio axis and has high fractional polarization Subject headings galaxies individual galaxies jets radio cont in um galaxies

Theory of non Markov ian Stochastic Resonance Igor Goy ch uk and Peter Hang gi Institute of Physics University of Augsburg Universitat str Augsburg Germany Dated October We consider two state model of non Markov ian stochastic resonance SR within the framework of the theory of renewal processes Residence time intervals are assumed to be mutually independent and characterized by some arbitrary non exponential residence time distributions which are mod late in time by an externally applied signal Making use of stochastic path integral approach we obtain general integral equations governing the evolution of conditional probabilities in the pre en ce of an input signal These novel equations generalize earlier integral renewal equations by Cox and others to the case of driving induced non station ari ty On the basis of these new equations response theory of two state renewal processes is formulated beyond the linear response approx mati on Moreover general expression for the linear response function is derived The connection of the developed approach with the phenom eno logical theory of linear response for manifest non Markov ian SR put forward in Goy ch uk and Hang gi Ph ys Rev Let is la ried and its range of validity is scrutinized The novel theory is then applied to SR in symmetric non Markov ian systems and to the class of single ion channels possessing fractal kinetics PAC numbers Uv Uv Keywords single molecules non Markov ian eec ts fractal renewal processes noise stochastic reso nance

On Ver va at and Ver va at error type processes for partial sums and renewals End re saki Alfred Re nyi Institute of Mathematics Hungarian Academy of Sciences Budapest Hungary mail saki re nyi hu Miklos Csor go School of Mathematics and Statistics Carleton University Ottawa Ontario Canada Mail mcs or go math carleton ca dz is law Ry chl ik In sty tut Mate mat ki Uni wer sy tet Mari Curie Sk lo dow ski ej pl Mari Curie Sk lo dow ski ej PL Lublin Poland Mail ry chl ik go lem mcs lublin pl Josef Stein bach Universitat zu Kol Ma them at is che Institut Weyer tal Kol Germany Mail jost math uni ko el de Abstract We study the asymptotic behaviour of stochastic processes that are generated by sums of partial sums of random variables and their renewals We conclude that these processes cannot converge weakly to any non degenerate random element of the space On the other hand we show that their properly normalized integrals as Ver va at type stochastic processes converge weakly to squared Wiener process Moreover we also deal with the asymptotic behaviour of the deviations of these processes the so called Ver va at error type processes Keywords Partial sums renewals Ver va at and Ver va at error type processes Wiener process strong and weak approximations weak convergence Mathematics Subject Classic ation Primary secondary Research supported by the Hungarian National Foundation for Sci en tic Research Grant No and Research supported by an NSE RC Canada Grant at Carleton University Ottawa Research supported by the Deutsche For chung gemeinschaft through the German Polish project POL Probability measures Research supported by Polish German Exchange Grant No WM III DA AD JK and by special grant from Marie Curie Sk odowska University Lublin

Fractal time random walk and sub recoil laser cooling considered as renewal processes with in nite mean waiting times Bar dou IP CMS CNRS and Universit Louis Pasteur rue du Loe BP Strasbourg Cede France There exist important stochastic physical processes involving in nite mean waiting times The mean divergence has dramatic consequences on the process dynamics Fractal time random walks diu sion process and sub recoil laser cooling concentration process are two such processes that look qualitatively dissimilar Yet unifying treatment of these two processes which is the topic of this pedagogic paper can be developed by combining renewal theory with the generalized central limit theorem This approach enables to derive without technical di cul ties the key physical properties and it emphasizes the role of the behaviour of sums with in nite means To appear in Proceedings of Car ges Summer School on between fractal time random walk and sub recoil laser Chaotic Dynamics and Transport in Classical and Quantum cooling We show that the essential results of the two Systems August theories can be obtained nearly without calculation by combining the simple probabilistic reasoning underlying renewal theory and the generalized central limit theorem

Fluorescence inter mitten cy in blinking quantum dots renewal or slow modulation Simone Bianco Paolo Gri gol in and Paolo Paradisi Center for Nonlinear Science University of North Texas Box Denton Texas USA Is it to dei Process him ico is ici del CNR Area della Rice rca di Pisa Via Mo ruz zi Pisa Italy Di parti men to di Fi sica Fermi Universit di Pisa Largo Ponte cor vo PISA and IS AC CNR se zi one di Lecce strada provincial Lecce Montero ni km Lecce Dated October We study time series produced by the blinking quantum dots by means of an aging experiment and we examine the results of this experiment in the light of two distinct approaches to complexity renewal and slow modulation Wend that the renewal approach ts the result of the aging ex per ment while the slow modulation perspective does not We make also an attempt at establishing the existence of an intermediate condition PAC numbers Fb Tp Bh Hc

Viability Analysis of Management Frameworks for Fisheries Eisen ck chef fran and Kr opp Potsdam Institute for Climate Impact Research Box Potsdam Germany eisen ck pi potsdam de kr opp pi potsdam de University of Illinois International Programs and Studies ACD IS Armory Ave Champaign IL USA chef fra uiuc edu Abstract The pressure on marine renewable resources has rapidly increased over past decades The resulting scarcity has led to variety of different control and sur veil lance instruments Often they have not improved the current situation mainly due to institutional failure and intrinsic uncertainties about the state of stocks This contribution presents an assessment of different management schemes with respect top rede ned constraints by utilizing viability theory Our analysis is based on bio economic model which is examined as dynamic control system in cont in us time Feasible development paths are discussed in detail It is shown that participatory management may lead to serious problems if purely resource based management strategy is employed The analysis suggests that less risky manage ment strategy can be implemented if limited data are available

SHARP ASYMPTOTIC BEHAVIOR FOR WETTING MODELS IN DIMENSION FRANCESCO CA RAVENNA GIA BATTISTA GIACOMIN AND LORENZO ZAMBO TT Abstract We consider continuous and discrete dimensional wetting models which undergo localization delocalization phase transition Using simple approach based on Renewal Theory we determine the precise asymptotic behavior of the partition function from which we obtain the scaling limits of the models and an explicit const ruc tion of the in nite volume measure thermodynamic limit in all regimes including the critical one

ESTIMATION IN SEMI PARAMETRIC MODULATED RENEWAL PROCESS Do rota Dab row ska University of California Los Angeles Wai Tung Ho PSS Inc Chicago Abstract We consider parameter estimation in regression model corresponding to an ii sequence of censored observations of nite state modulated renewal process The model assumes similar form as in Cox regression except that the baseline intensities are functions of the backwards recurrence time of the process and time dependent co variate As result of this it falls outside the class of multiplicative intensity counting process models We use kernel estimation to construct estimates of the regression coe ci ents and baseline cumulative hazards We give conditions for consistency and asymptotic normality of estimates Data from bone marrow transplant study are used to illustrate the results Keywords and phrases Modulated renewal process kernel estimation processes

Renewal aging and linear response Paolo Allegri ni Gianluca As colan Mauro Bologna and Paolo Gri gol in Di parti men to di Fi sica Fermi Universit di Pisa Largo Ponte cor vo Pisa Italy Depart men to de Fi sica Universidad de Tarapaca Campus Velasquez Velasquez Ca silla Arica Chile Center for Nonlinear Science University of North Texas Box Denton Texas USA and Is it to dei Process him ico is ici del CNR Area della Rice rca di Pisa Via Mo ruz zi Pisa Italy Dated October We study the linear response to an external perturbation of renewal process in an aging cond tion that with no perturbation would yield super diu sion We use the phenom eno logical approach to the linear response adopted in earlier work of other groups and we nd that aging may have the eec of annihilating any sign of coherent response to harmonic perturbation We also derive the linear response using dynamic arguments and we nd coherent response although with an intensity dying out very slowly In the case of step like perturbation the dynamic arguments yield in the long time limit steady signal whose intensity may be sign cant ly smaller than the phenom eno logical approach prediction PAC numbers Fb Uv

INFINITE VOLUME LIMITS OF POLYMER CHAINS WITH PERIODIC CHARGES FRANCESCO CA RAVENNA GIA BATTISTA GIACOMIN AND LORENZO ZAMBO TT Abstract The aim of this paper is twofold To give an elementary and self contained proof of an explicit formula for the free energy for general class of polymer chains interacting with an environment through periodic potentials This generalizes result in in which the formula is derived by using the Don sker Var adhan Large Deviations theory for Markov chains We exploit instead tools from renewal theory To identify the in nite volume limits of the system In particular in the die rent regimes we encounter transient null recurrent and positive recurrent processes which correspond to delocalized critical and localized behaviors of the trajectories This is done by exploiting the sharp estimates on the partition function of the system obtained by the renewal theory approach The precise characterization of the in nite volume limits of the system exposes non uniqueness problem We will however explain in detail how this at rst surprising phenomenon is instead due to the presence of rst order phase transition Mathematics Subject Classic ation Keywords Random Walks Markov Renewal Theory Polymers In nite volume limits Gibbs measures Phase transitions

Non anchored Unie Naming System for Ad Hoc Computing Environments Yoo Chul Chung Dong man Lee August Abstract ubiquitous computing environment consists of many resources that need to be den tied by users and applications Users and developers require some way to identify resources by human readable names In addition ubiquitous computing environments impose additional require ment such as the ability to work well with ad hoc situations and the provision of names that depend on context The Non anchored Unie Naming NUN system was designed to at is fy these requirements It is based on relative naming among resources and provides the ability to name arbitrary types of resources By ha ing resources themselves take part in naming resources are able to able contribute their specialized knowledge into the name resolution process making context dependent mapping of names to resources possible The ease of which new resource types can be added makes it simple to in cor po rate new types of contextual information within names In this paper we describe the naming system and evaluate its use

IMS Lecture Notes Monograph Series Recent Developments in Non parametric Inference and Probability Vol cid Institute of Mathematical Statistics DOI Nonlinear renewal theorems for random walks with perturbations of intermediate order Keiji Nagai and un Hui Zhang Yokohama National University and Rutgers University Abstract We develop nonlinear renewal theorems for perturbed random walk without assuming stochastic bounded ness of centered perturbation terms second order expansion of the expected stopping time is obtained via the uniform in te gr ability of the die rence between certain linear and nonlinear stopping rules An intermediate renewal theorem is obtained which provides expansions between the nonlinear versions of the elementary and regular re new al theorems The expected sample size of two sample rank sequential probability ratio testis considered as the motivating example

CORRELATION LENGTHS FOR RANDOM POLYMER MODELS AND FOR SOME RENEWAL SEQUENCES FABIO LUCIO TO NINE LLI Abstract We consider models of directed polymers interacting with one dimensional defect line on which random charges are placed More abstractly one starts from re new al sequence on and gives random site dependent reward or penalty to the occurrence of renewal at any given point of These models are known to undergo delocalization localization transition and the free energy vanishes when the critical point is approached from the localized region We prove that the quenched correlation length de ned as the inverse of the rate of exponential decay of the two point function does not diverge faster than We prove also an exponentially decaying upper bound for the disorder averaged two point function with good control of the sub exponential pre factor We discuss how in the particular case where disorder is absent this result can be seen as rene ment of the classical renewal theorem for spec ic class of renewal sequences Mathematics Subject Classic ation Keywords Pinning and Wetting Models Typical and Average Correlation Lengths Crit ical Exponents Renewal Theory Exponential Convergence Rates

FRA CALM PRE PRINT ww fra calm org Published in Vietnam Journal of Mathematics Vol SI pp Springer Verlag ISSN fractional generalization of the Poisson processes Francesco MAIN ARD Rudolf GORE NFL Enrico SCALA Di parti men to di Fi sica Universit di Bologna and IN FN Via rne rio Bologna Italy mail main ard bo in fn it URL www fra calm org First Mathematical Institute Free University of Berlin Arni mallee Berlin Germany mail gore nfl mi fu berlin de Di parti men to di Sci enz Tec no logie van ate Universit del Piemonte Orientale via Cavour Alessandria Italy mail scala unip mn it Abstract It is our intention to provide via fractional calculus generalization of the pure and compound Poisson processes which are known to play fundamental role in renewal theory without and with reward respectively We rst recall the basic renewal theory including its fundamental concepts like waiting time between events the survival probability the counting function If the waiting time is exponentially distributed we have Poisson process which is Markov ian However other waiting time distributions are also relevant in applications in particular such ones with fat tail caused by power law decay of its density In this context we analyze an on Markov ian renewal process with waiting time distribution described by the Mit tag Leer function This distribution containing the exponential as particular case is shown to play fundamental role in the in nite thinning procedure of generic renewal process governed by power asymptotic waiting time We then consider the renewal theory with reward that implies random walk subordinated to renewal process MSC Key words Renewal theory Poisson process Er lang distribution fractional derivatives Mit tag Leer function thinning procedure random walks

Irving Kaplan sky and Supersymmetry Peter Freund Enrico Fermi Institute and Department of Physics University of Chicago Chicago IL Abstract Remarks at the Irving Kaplan sky Memorial about collaboration during the early period of the renewal of contacts between mathematicians and theoretical physicists arrived in Chicago some two decades after Irving Kaplan sky and met Kap as we all called him shortly after my arrival here We became friends later in while collaborating on paper on supersymmetry Lie super algebras graded counterparts of ordinary Lie algebras play central role in string theory and other unie theories classic ation of the simple ones was of essence took some initial steps but the real work started when itz Her stein put me in touch with Kap At rst communication was not easy We couldnt quite make out each others reasoning much as we agreed on results It didnt take long however to get used to the others way of looking at things Mathematicians and physicists think in similar ways after all all that was needed was dictionary This was during the early phase of the rapprochement between ma the ma tics and theoretical physics After the glorious rst half of the twentieth century when the likes of Poincar Hilbert We yl von Neumann Elie Car tan Emmy No ether and others made major contributions to the then new physical theories of general relativity and quantum mechanics while ph ys cist like Jordan Dirac Casimir and Feynman made major contributions to Based on remarks at the Irving Kaplan sky Memorial atM SRI Berkeley Ca February freund theory chicago edu

PROBABILISTIC REPRESENTATION OF CONSTANTS IN KES TENS RENEWAL THEOREM NATHANAEL ENRIQUE CHRISTOPHE BOT AND OLIVIER INDY Abstract The aims of this paper are twofold Firstly we derive probabilistic representation for the constant which appears in the one dimensional case of Kes tens renewal theorem Secondly we estimate the tail of related random variable which plays an essential role in the description of the stable limit law of one dimensional transient sub ballistic random walks in random environment

The Annals of Applied Probability Vol No DOI cid Institute of Mathematical Statistics RENEWALS FOR EXPONENTIALLY INCREASING LIFETIMES WITH AN APPLICATION TO DIGITAL SEARCH TREES By Florian Denn ert and Rudolf rubel Universitat Hannover We show that the number of renewals up to time exhibits is tri but iona luc tu at ions as tif the underlying lifetimes increase at an exponential rate in distribution al sense This provides pro ba bilis tic explanation for the asymptotic of insertion depth in random trees generated by bit comparison strategy from uniform input we also obtain representation for the resulting family of limit laws along sub sequences Our approach can also be used to obtain rates of convergence

Secure sharing of random bits over the Internet Geraldo Barbosa Quanta Sec Research in Quantum Cryptography Ltd Portugal Ave Belo Horizonte MG Brazil Dated May Although one time pad encrypted les can be sent through Internet channels the need for re new ing shared secret keys have made this method un practical This work presents scheme to turn practical the fast sharing of random keys over arbitrary Internet channels Starting with shared secret key sequence of length the users end up with secure new sequence Using these sequences for posterior message encryption the legitimate users have absolute security control without the need for third parties Additionally the security level does not depend on the unproven di cult of factoring numbers in primes In the proposed scheme fast optical random source generates random bits and noise for key renewals The transmitted signals are recorded sig nal that carries both the random binary signals to be exchanged and physical noise that cannot be eliminated by the attacker These signals allow amp li cation over the Internet network with out degrading security The proposed system is also secure against posterior known plaintext attack on the key Information theoretic analysis is presented and bounds for secure operation are quantitatively determined PAC Ca Ar Dd

RENEWAL CONVERGENCE RATES AND CORRELATION DECAY FOR HOMOGENEOUS PINNING MODELS GIA BATTISTA GIACOMIN Abstract class of discrete renewal processes with super exponentially decaying inter arrival distributions coincides with the in nite volume limit of general homo ge neo us pinning models in their localized phase Pinning models are statistical mechanics systems to which lot of attention has been devoted both for their relevance for app li cations and because they are solvable models exhibiting non trivial phase transition The spatial decay of correlations in these systems is directly mapped to the speed of convergence to equilibrium for the associated renewal processes We show that close to critical it under general assumptions the correlation decay rate or the renewal con ver gence rate coincides with the inter arrival decay rate We also show that in general this is false away from critical it Under stronger assumption on the inter arrival dist rib tion we establish local limit theorem capturing thus the sharp asymptotic behavior of correlations Keywords Renewal Theory Speed of Convergence to Equilibrium Super exponential Tails Pinning Models Decay of Correlations Critical it AMS Subject Classic ation Numbers

The Annals of Probability Vol No DOI OP cid Institute of Mathematical Statistics ON THE IRRELEVANT DISORDER REGIME OF PINNING MODELS By Gia battista Giacomin and Fabio Lucio To nine lli Universit Paris Diderot and ENS Lyon Recent results have lead to substantial progress in understand ing the role of disorder in the de localization transition of polymer pinning models Notably there is an understanding of the crucial is sue of disorder relevance and irrelevance that is now rigorous In this work we exploit interpolation and replica coupling methods to obtain sharper results on the irrelevant disorder regime of pinning models In particular in this regime we compute the rst order term in the expansion of the free energy close to critical it and this term coin cide with the rst order of the formal expansion obtained by el theory methods We also show that the quenched and quenched av raged correlation length exponents coincide while in general they are expected to be die rent Interpolation and replica coupling meth od in this class of models naturally lead to studying the behavior of the intersection of certain renewal sequences and one of the main tools in this work is precisely renewal theory and the study of these intersection renewals

Statistical Science Vol No DOI cid Institute of Mathematical Statistics On the Statistical Modeling and Analysis of Repairable Systems Bo Henry Lind qv is Abstract We review basic modeling approaches for failure and main ten ance data from repairable systems In particular we consider im perfect repair models de ned in terms of virtual age processes and the trend renewal process which extends the non homogeneous Poisson process and the renewal process In the case where several systems of the same kind are observed we show how observed co variate and un observed heterogeneity can be included in the models We also consider various approaches to trend testing Modern reliability data bases usu ally contain information on the type of failure the type of maintenance and so forth in addition to the failure times themselves Basing our work on recent literature we present framework where the observed events are modeled as marked point processes with marks labeling the types of events Throughout the paper the emphasis is more on modeling than on statistical inference Key words and phrases Repairable system preventive maintenance non homogeneous Poisson process renewal process marked point pro ces virtual age process trend renewal process heterogeneity trend competing risks

note on the convergence of renewal and regenerative processes to Brownian bridge erg uei Foss Tak is Kon stan to poul os August Abstract The standard functional central limit theorem for renewal process with nite mean and variance results in Brownian motion limit This note show show to obtain Brow ni an bridge process by direct procedure that does not involve conditioning Several examples are also considered Keywords and phrases Renewal process Brownian bridge functional central limit theorem weak convergence AMS subject classic at ions Primary secondary The basic theorem In proving convergence results for stochastic ordered graph on the integers we noticed that one can obtain Don sker like theorem for Brownian bridge in somewhat non standard manner The result appears to be new As it may be of potential interest in some related areas statistics large deviations we summarise it in this short note Consider possibly delayed renewal process on with renewal epochs We assume that are with mean and variance both nite Let be the associated counting process The standard functional central limit theorem for renewal process see states that the sequence of processes where nt nt converges weakly as to where is standard Brownian motion on Weak convergence denoted by below means weak convergence of probability

EP manuscript No will be inserted by the editor Renewal equations for option pricing Miquel Montero Depart ment de sica Fon mental Universitat de Barcelona Diagonal Barcelona Spain mail miquel montero ub edu October Abstract In this paper we will develop methodology for obtaining pricing expressions for nanci lins tru ment whose underlying asset can be described through simple continuous time random walk CT RW market model Our approach is very natural to the issue because it is based in the use of renewal equations and therefore it enhances the potential use of CT RW techniques in nance We solve these equations for typical contract spec cations in particular but exemplifying case We also show how formal general solution can be found for more exotic derivatives and we compare prices for alternative models of the underlying Finally we recover the celebrated results for the Wiener process under certain limits PAC Gh Economics eco no physics nanci al markets business and management Fb Ran dom walks and Levy ig ht Ey Stochastic processes

Excitable systems with noise and delay with applications to control renewal theory approach Andrey Pot ot sky and Natalia Janson Department of Mathematical Sciences Loughborough University Loughborough Leicestershire LE TU United Kingdom Dated October We present an approach for the analytical treatment of excitable systems with noise induced dynamics in the presence of time delay An excitable system is modeled as bistable system with time delay while another delay enters as control term taken after Pyr gas sadie rence between the current system state and its state time units before This approach combines the elements of renewal theory to estimate the essential features of the resulting stochastic process as functions of the parameters of the controlling term PAC numbers Uv Ks

Controlled de coherence in quantum Levy kicked rotator Henning Sc homer us Department of Physics Lancaster University Lancaster LA YB UK Eric Lutz Department of Physics University of Augsburg Augsburg Germany Dated November We develop theory describing the dynamics of quantum kicked rotator modelling cold atoms in pulsed optical el which are subjected to combined amplitude and timing noise generated by renewal process acting as an engineered reservoir For waiting time distributions of variable exponent Levy noise we demonstrate the existence of regime of non exponential loss of phase coherence In this regime the momentum dynamics is sub diu sive which also manifests itself in non Gaussian limiting distribution and fractional power law decay of the inverse participation ratio The purity initially decays with stretched exponential which is followed by two regimes of power law decay with die rent exponents The averaged logarithm of the del it probes the sprinkling distribution of the renewal process These analytical results are con med by numerical computations on quantum kicked rotator subjected to noise events generated by Yule Simon distribution PAC numbers Yz Fb Rn

Finite size scaling for homogeneous pinning models Julien So hier Universit Paris Diderot LP MA Ma the mati ques case place Jussieu Paris Cede France mail address so hier math jussieu fr Abstract Pinning models are built from discrete renewal sequences by rewarding or penalizing the trajectories according to their number of renewal epochs up to time and is then sent to inn it They are statistical mechanics mod els to which lot of attention has been paid both because they are very relevant for applications and because of their exactly solvable character while displaying non trivial phase transition in fact localization transition The order of the transition depends on the tail of the inter arrival law of the underlying renewal and the transition is continuous when such tail is uci ent ly heavy this is the case on which we will focus The main purpose of this work is to give mathematical treatment of the nite size scaling limit of pinning models namely studying the limit in law of the process close to critical it when the system size is proportional to the correlation length

Renewal type Limit Theorem for Continued Fractions with Even Partial Quotients Francesco Cellar osi August Abstract We prove the existence of the limiting distribution for the sequence of denominators generated by continued fraction expansions with even partial quotients which were introduced by Sch we iger and studied also by Kr aik amp and Lopes Our main result is proven following the strategy used by Ya Sinai and Ul cig rai in their proof of similar renewal type theorem for Euclidean continued fraction expansions and the Gauss map The main steps in our proof are the construction of natural extension of Gauss like map and the proof of mixing of related special ow

On the ruin problem in the renewal risk processes perturbed by diu sion Min Song Abstract In this paper we consider the perturbed renewal risk process Systems of in te gro dieren ti al equations for the Gerber Shi functions at ruin caused by claim and oscillation are established respectively The explicit Lap las transforms of Gerber Shi functions are obtained while the closed form expressions for the Gerber Shi functions are derived when the claim amount distribution is from the rational family Finally we present numerical examples intended to illustrate the main results Keywords Diu sion process Gerber Shi discounted penalty function Renewal risk process Mathematics Subject Classic ation Corresponding author School of Mathematical Sciences Nankai University Tianjin China mail nk song min yahoo com cn Song

Kish Said UNCONDITIONALLY SECURE COMPUTERS ALGORITHMS AND HARDWARE SUCH AS MEMORIES PROCESSORS KEYBOARDS FLASH AND HARD DRIVES cid LASZLO KISH AND OLIVIER SAID Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering Texas University College Station TX USA CRT Capital Holdings LLC Harbor Drive Stamford CT USA Version April In the case of the need of extraordinary security Kirchhoff loop Johnson like noise ciphers can easily be integrated on existing types of digital chips in order to provide secure data communication between hardware processors memory chips hard disks and other units within computer or other data processor system The secure key exchange can take place at the very first run and the system can renew the key later at random times with an authenticated fashion to prohibit man in the middle attack The key can be stored in flash memories within the communicating chip units at hidden random addresses among other random bits that are continuously generated by the secure line but are never actually used Thus even if the system is disassembled and the eavesdropper can have direct access to the communication lines between the units or even if she is trying to use man in the middle attack no information can be extracted The only way to break the code is to learn the chip structure to understand the machine code program and to read out the information during running by accessing the proper internal ports of the working chips However such an attack needs extraordinary resources and even that can be prohibited by password lockout The unconditional security of commercial algorithms against piracy can be provided in similar way Keywords secure memories secure microprocessors secure hard drives secure hardware When computer is lost even if it is password protected after disassembling it the information stored in it will be accessible Similarly if flash memory and portable hard drive backups are insecure To defend against these problems data can be encrypted by software tools However these software encryption keys have limited security they maybe eavesdropped guessed or broken if they are not sufficiently long The solution described in this short note offers much higher level of data security by providing unconditionally secure data communication between the hardware elements of interest Quantum encryption is an example where with the help of the laws of physics secure data communication is achieved However those instruments are bulky and the price of pair of communicators is around which make them insufficient for this task Recently statistical physics based circuitry the Kirchhoff loop Johnson like noise KL JN cipher was proposed as an electronic competitor of quantum communicators see Figure To detect the eavesdropper the KL JN system does not need to build statistics like quantum communicators do and even the communication of single bit is secure This is the only communicator which is cid http www ar xiv org abs

Energy Strategy Energy Real polit ik Towards Sustainable Energy Strategy Udo Schr der Departments of Chemistry and Physics University of Rochester Rochester Schroeder chem rochester edu Abstract long term strategy based on existing technological ecological economical and geopolitical realities is urgently needed to develop sustainable energy economy which should be designed with adaptability to un predicted changes in any of these aspects While only highly diverse energy portfolio and conservation can ultimately guarantee optimum sustainability based on comparison of current primary energy generation methods it is argued that future energy strategy has to rely heavily on expanded coal and nuclear energy sectors comparison of relative potentials merits and risks as so cia ted with fossil fuel renewable and nuclear technologies suggests that the balance of technologies should be shifted in favor of new generation safe nuclear methods to pro duce electricity while clean coal plants should be assigned to transportation fuel Novel nuclear technologies exploit fission of uranium and thorium as primary energy sources with fast spectrum and transmutation burner reactors closed fuel cycle and waste transmutation resolve the strategic issues associated with nuclear power Innovative reactor designs utilizes pall ation of heavy metals in sub critical accelerator driven systems or molten salt reactors Importation and reconstruction of technical expertise already lost and version of further erosion are preconditions to any successful energy strategy Research opportunities to perfect innovative nuclear coal and renewable energy tech no logie should be pursued Keywords sustainable energy economy clean coal and advanced nuclear energy systems

RENEWAL SERIES AND SQUARE ROOT BOUNDARIES FOR BESSEL PROCESSES NATHANAEL ENRIQUE CHRISTOPHE BOT AND MARC OR Abstract We show how description of Brownian exponential functional as renewal series gives access to the law of the hitting time of square root boundary by Bessel process This extends classical results by Bre iman and She pp concerning Brownian motion and recovers by die rent means extensions for Bessel processes obtained independently by De long and or Let be the standard real valued Brownian motion and for introduce the geometric Brownian motion and its exponential functional exp ds Lamp ert is representation theorem applied to states where denotes the Bessel process of index equivalently of dimension starting at which is an valued diu sion with in nites mal generator given by Let us remark that in the special case equation is nothing else but the Dub in Schwarz representation of the exponential martin gale as Brownian motion time changed with For short summary of relations between Bessel processes and exponentials of Brownian motion see or Let us consider now the following random variable which is often called per pet it in the mathematical nance literature ds We deduce directly from that Mathematics Subject Classic ation Key words and phrases Bessel processes renewal series exponential functional square root boundaries

Quenched large deviation principle for words in letter sequence Matthias Birk ner Andreas Greven Frank den Hollander th May Abstract When we cut an sequence of letters into words according to an independent renewal process we obtain an sequence of words In the annealed large deviation principle LDP for the empirical process of words the rate function is the spec ic relative entropy of the observed law of words the reference law of words In the present paper we consider the quenched LDP we condition on typical letter sequence We focus on the case where the renewal process has an algebraic tail The rate function turns out to be sum of two terms one being the annealed rate function the other being proportional to the spec ic relative entropy of the observed law of letters the reference law of letters with the former being obtained by concatenating the words and random ising the location of the origin The proportionality constant equals the tail exponent of the renewal process Earlier work by Birk ner considered the case where the renewal process has an exponential tail in which case the rate function turns out to be the rst term on the set where the second term vanishes and to be in nite elsewhere In companion paper the annealed and the quenched LDP are applied to the collision local time of transient random walks and the existence of an intermediate phase for class of interacting stochastic systems is established Key words Letters and words renewal process empirical process annealed vs quenched large deviation principle rate function spec ic relative entropy MSC Acknowledgement This work was supported in part by FG and NWO through the Dutch German Bilateral Research Group Mathematics of Random Spatial Models from Physics and Biology BandAG are Providing Virtual Execution Environments Twofold Illustration open lab Internal May Xavier rehan and Dana CERN open lab Geneva Switzerland Abstract Platform virtualization helps solving major grid computing challenges share resource with ex ble user controlled and custom exe cut ion environments and in the meanwhile isolate failures and malicious code Grid resource management tools will evolve to embrace support for virtual resource We present two open source projects that transparently supply virtual execution environments Tycoon has been developed at HP Labs to op tim is resource usage in creating an economy where users bid to access virtual machines and compete for CPU cycles Smart Domains provides peer to peer layer that automates virtual machines deployment using description language and deployment engine from HP Labs These projects demonstrate both client server and peer to peer approaches to virtual resource management The rst case makes extensive use of vi tu al machines features for dynamic resource allocation The second trans late virtual machines capabilities into sophisticated language where resource management components can be plugged in cong rations and architectures de ned at deployment time We propose to share our experience at CERN open lab developing Smart Domains and deploying Tycoon to give an illustrative introduction to emerging research in virtual resource management

Integrating uc tu at ions into distribution of resources in transportation networks Shan He Sheng Li and Hong ru Ma Department Of Physics Shanghai Jiao Tong University Shanghai Peoples Republic of China Dated November Abstract We propose are source distribution strategy to reduce the average travel time in transportation network given axed generation rate Suppose that there are essential resources to avoid congestion in the network as well as some extra resources The strategy distributes the essential resources by the average loads on the vertices and integrates the uc tu at ions of the instantaneous loads into the distribution of the extra resources The uc tu at ions are calculated with the assumption of unlimited resources where the calculation is incorporated into the calculation of the average loads without adding to the time complexity Simulation results show that the uc tu ation integrated strategy provides shorter average travel time than previous distribution strategy while keeping similar robustness the strategy is especially bene cia when the extra resources are scarce and the network is heterogeneous and lowly loaded PAC numbers Hc Electronic address li sheng sj tu edu cn

Non Markov ian non stationary completely positive open quantum system dynamics Adrian Bud in and Paolo Gri gol in Consejo Nacional de Investigation es Cie nt cas Tec nica Centro Atomic Bari loc he Avenida Bu still Km Bari loc he Argentina Center for Nonlinear Science University of North Texas Box Denton Texas USA Is it to dei Process him ico is ici del CNR Area della Rice rca di Pisa Via Mo ruz zi Pisa Italy and Di parti men to di Fi sica Fermi Universit di Pisa Largo Ponte cor vo Pisa Italy Dated November By modeling the interaction of system with an environment through renewal approach we demonstrate that completely positive non Markov ian dynamics may develop some unexplored non standard statistical properties The renewal approach is de ned by set of disruptive events consisting in the action of completely positive super operator over the system density matrix The random time intervals between events are described by an arbitrary waiting time distribution We show that in contrast to the Markov ian case if one performs system preparation measurement at an arbitrary time the subsequent evolution of the density matrix evolution is mo died The non stationary character refers to the absence of an asymptotic master equation even when the preparation is performed at arbitrary long times In spite of this property we demonstrate that op erat or expectation values and operators correlations have the same dynamical structure establishing the validity of an on stationary quantum regression hypothesis The non stationary property of the dynamic is also analyzed through the response of the system to an external weak perturbation PAC numbers Yz Lc Ta

The Future of Nuclear Energy Facts and Fiction Chapter III How un reliable are the Red Book Uranium Resource Data Michael it mar Institute of Particle Physics ETH Zurich Switzerland October Abstract For more than years the Nuclear Energy Agency of the OECD countries and the International Atomic Energy Administration of the United Nations have published biannual document with the title Uranium Resources Production and Demand This book known as the Red Book summarizes data about the actual and near future nuclear energy situation and presents the accumulated worldwide knowledge about the existing and expected uranium resources These data are widely believed to provide an accurate and solid basis for future decisions about nuclear energy Unfortunately as it is demonstrated in this paper they do not The conventional worldwide uranium resources are estimated by the authors of the Red Book as million tons Out of these million tons are assigned to the reasonable assured category and million tons are associated with the not yet discovered but assumed to exist inferred resources Our analysis shows that neither the million tons of assured resources nor the million tons of inferred resources are jus tied by the Red Book data and that the actual known exploit able resources are probably much smaller Despite many shortcomings of the uranium resource data some interesting and valuable information can be extracted from the Red Book Perhaps most importantly the Red Book resource data can be used to test the economic geological hypothesis which claims for example that doubling of uranium price will increase the amount exploit able uranium resources by an even larger factor The relations between the uranium resources claimed for the die rent resource categories and their associated cost estimates are found to be in clear contradiction with this hypothesis mail Michael it mar cern ch

Non equilibrium dynamics of stochastic point processes with refractor in ess Moritz De ger Moritz He lias Stefano Cardano bile Fat ih can tay and Stefan otter Bernstein Center Freiburg Faculty of Biology Albert Ludwig University Freiburg Germany RIKEN Brain Science Institute Wako City Saitama Japan Max Planck Institute for Mathematics in the Sciences Leipzig Germany Dated November Stochastic point processes with refractor in ess appear frequently in the quantitative analysis of physical and biological systems such as the generation of action potentials by nerve cells the release and reuptake of vesicles at synapse and the counting of particles by detector devices Here we present an extension of renewal theory to describe ensembles of point processes with time varying input This is made possible by representation in terms of occupation numbers of two states Active and refractory The dynamics of these occupation numbers follows distributed delay dieren ti al equation In particular our theory enables us to uncover the eec of refractor in ess on the time dependent rate of an ensemble of encoding point processes in response to modulation of the input We present exact solutions that demonstrate generic features such as stochastic transients and oscillations in the step response as well as resonances phase jumps and frequency doubling in the transfer of periodic signals We show that large class of renewal processes can indeed be regarded as special cases of the model we analyze Hence our approach represents widely applicable framework to de ne and analyze non stationary renewal processes PAC numbers Ey ll

International journal of Computer Networks Communications JC NC Vol No March SOURCE PRICING IN YNA MIC UL TI OM MODI TY ARK ET FOR OM PUT AT IONAL SOURCES Abdel kader Broeck hove and Van mechelen Department of Mathematics and Computer Sciences University of Antwerp Antwerp Belgium Khalid Abdel kader ac be Kurt Van mechelen ac be Jan Broeck hove ac be ABSTRACT The adoption of market based principles in resource management systems for computational infrastructures such as grids and clusters allows for matching demand and supply for resources in utility maximizing manner As such they offer promise of producing more efficient resource allocations compared to traditional system centric approaches that do not allow consumers and providers to express their valuations for computational resources In this paper we investigate the pricing of resources in grids through the use of computational commodity market of CPU resources where resource prices are determined through the computation of supply and demand equilibrium In particular we introduce several categories of CPUs characterized by their execution speed These differ in cost and performance but may be used interchangeably in executing jobs and thus represent so called subst it table resources We investigate the performance of the algorithms for computing the supply and demand equilibrium in this multi commodity setting under dynamically varying consumer and provider populations KEYWORDS Commodity Market Spot Market Dynamic Grids Grid Economics Resource Management Scheduling Subst it table Resources

Perturbation approach to scaled type Markov renewal processes with in nite mean olt Pa or Gyula Do mok os Sz as December Abstract Scaled type Markov renewal processes generalize classical renewal pro esse renewal times come from one parameter family of probability laws and the sequence of the parameters is the trajectory of an ergo dic Markov chain Our primary interest here is the asymptotic distribution of the Markov ian parameter at time The limit of course depends on the stationary distribution of the Markov chain The results however are essentially different depending on whether the expectations of there new als are nite or in nite If the expectations are uniformly bounded then we can provide the limit in general beyond the class of scaled type processes where the expectations of the probability laws in question ap pear too If the means are in nite then by assuming that the renewal times are re scaled versions of regularly varying probability law with ex pone nt it is the exponent which emerges in the limits

Lagging Leading Coupled Continuous Time Random Walks Renewal Times and their Joint Limits Henry St raka Department of Applied Mathematics School of Mathematics and Statistics University of New South Wales Sydney NSW Australia Abstract Subordinating random walk to renewal process yields continuous time random walk CT RW model for diu sion including the possibility of anomalous diu sion Transition densities of scaling limits of power law CT RWs have been shown to solve fractional Fokker Planck equations We consider limits of sequences of CT RWs which arise when both waiting times and jumps are taken from an in nites mal triangular array We identify two die rent limit processes and when waiting times precede or follow jumps respectively In the limiting procedure we keep track of the renewal times of the CT RWs and hence nd two more limit processes Finally we calculate the joint law of all four limit processes evaluated at ed time

Novel Characteristics of Split Trees by use of Renewal Theory Cecilia Holm gren Abstract We investigate characteristics of random split trees introduced by Dev roy split trees include for example binary search trees ary search trees quad trees median of trees simplex trees tries and digital search trees More precisely We introduce the use of renewal theory in the studies of split trees and use this theory to prove several results about split trees split tree of cardinality is constructed by distributing balls which often represent key numbers in subset of vertices of an in nite tree One of our main results is to give relation between the deterministic number of balls and the random number of vertices In there is central limit law for the depth of the last inserted ball so that most vertices cid cid are close to ln ln where is some constant depending on the type of split tree we sharpen this result by ding an upper bound for the expected number of vertices with depths ln ln cid or depths ln ln cid for any choice of cid We also nd the rst asymptotic of the variances of the depths of the balls in the tree

International Journal of Computer Science and Information Technology Volume Number June Efficient Resource Matching in Heterogeneous Grid Using Resource Vector Srirangam Adde pall il Per Andersen and George Barnes High Performance Computing Centre Texas Tech University Lubbock Texas mailto srirangam adde pall tu edu Department of Computer Science Texas Tech University Lubbock Texas mailto per andersen tu edu Department of Chemistry University of Oregon Eugen Oregon mailto barnes oregon edu ABSTRACT In this paper method for efficient scheduling to obtain optimum job throughput in distributed campus grid environment is presented Traditional job schedulers determine job scheduling using user and job resource attributes User attributes are related to current usage historical usage user priority and project access Job resource attributes mainly comprise of soft requirements compilers libraries and hard requirements like memory storage and interconnect job scheduler dispatches jobs to resource if jobs hard and soft requirements are met by resource In current scenario during execution of job if resource becomes unavailable schedulers are presented with limited options namely re queuing job or migrating job to different resource Both options are expensive in terms of data and compute time These situations can be avoided if the often ignored factor availability time of resource in grid environment is considered We propose resource rank approach in which jobs are dispatched to resource which has the highest rank among all resources that match the jobs requirement The results show that our approach can increase throughput of many serial monolithic jobs KEYWORDS GE SF Venus EN Dyne Condor

On approximation of functions satisfying defective renewal equations Sang esa Abstract Functions satisfying defective renewal equation arise commonly in applied probability models Usually these functions dont admit explicit expression In this work we consider to approximate them by means of gamma type operator given in terms of the Laplace transform of the initial function We investigate which conditions on the initial parameters of the renewal equation give optimal order of uniform convergence in the approximation We apply our results to ruin probability in the classical risk model paying special attention to mixtures of gamma claim amounts Mathematics subject classic ation Primary Secondary Key words and phrases defective renewal equation Laplace transform rate of convergence ruin probability gamma distribution

Are two resources really better than one Some unexpected results of the availability of substitutes Gian giacomo Bravo Lucia Tam buri no Abstract The possibility of exploiting multiple resources is usually regarded as positive from both the economic and the environmental point of view However resource switching may also lead to unsustainable growth and ultimately to an equilibrium condition which is worse than the one that could have been achieved with single resource We applied system dynamics model where users exploit multiple resources and have different levels of preference among them In this setting exploiting multiple resources leads to worse outcomes than the single resource case under wide range of parameter cong rations Our arguments are illustrated using two empirical situations namely oil drilling in the North Sea and whale hunting in the Antarctic Keywords resource management paradox of enrichment environmental sustainability

Hyper nuclear physics as seen by an experimenter Patrick chen bach Institut fur Kern ph sik Joh Gutenberg Universitat Mainz Germany In the new millennium hyper nuclear physics is undergoing renewed in te rest both theoretically and experimentally Hadrons and nuclei are understood as many body systems made of quarks and gluons bound by the strong force Information on baryon baryon inter actions is mainly obtained from nuclear experiments with projectiles and targets out of nucleons addressing interactions in av our SU only The di cul ties to study hyperon nucleon YN and hyperon hyperon YY inter actions by reaction experiments are related to the practical problems in the preparation of low energy hyperon beams and the impossibility of hyperon targets due to the short ps life times of hyperons The investigation of hyper nucleus where one or more nucleons have been replaced by one or more hyperons allows addressing rich spectrum of physics topics ranging from genuine nuclear physics to particle physics Although ft years have already passed since the discovery of the rst hyper nuclear events studies of hyper nuclei are still at the forefront of nuclear physics The presence of the hyperon can induce several eec ts on the host nucleus like changes of both size and shape mo dication of cluster structure manifestation on new symmetries or changes of nucleon collective motions One of the most spec acul ar eec ts observed so far in what is called impurity nuclear physics is the shrinking of the nucleus core Such behaviour can be considered precursor of matter condensation induced by strange particles Only recently it has already been demonstrated that hyper nuclei can be used as micro laboratory to study YN and YY interactions In the case of interaction the spin orbit term has been found to be smaller than that for

Renewal stochastic processes with correlated events Phase transitions along time evolution Jorge Velazquez and Alberto Rob le do Instituto de sica Universidad Nacional Autonoma de Mexico Apart do postal Mexico Mexico Depart men to de Mate mati cas Universidad Carlos III de Madrid Spain on sabbatical leave Dated October We consider renewal stochastic processes generated by non independent events from the per spec ti ve that their basic distribution and associated generating functions obey the statistical mechanical structure of systems with interacting degrees of freedom Based on this fact we look brie into the less known case of processes that display phase transitions along time When the density dist rib tion for the occurrence of the th event at time is considered to be partition function of micro canonical type for degrees of freedom at ed energy one obtains set of four partition functions of which that for the generating function variable and Laplace transform var able conjugate to and respectively plays central role These partition functions relate to each other in the customary way and in accordance to the precepts of large deviations theory while the entropy or Massieu potential derived from satis es an Euler relation We illustrate this scheme rst for an ordinary renewal process of events generated by simple exponential waiting time distribution Then we examine process modelled after the so called Hamiltonian Mean Field HM model that is representative of agents that perform repeated task with an associated outcome such as an opinion poll When sequence of many events takes place in uci ent ly short time the process exhibits clustering of the outcome but for larger times the process resembles that of independent events The two regimes are separated by sharp transition technically of the second order Finally we point out the existence of similar scheme for random walk processes PAC numbers Fh

Axiom at zing Resource Bounds for Measure Xiao yang Gu Jack Lutz Satya dev Nanda kumar and James Royer Linked In Corporation Mountain View CA gu linked in com Iowa State University Ames lutz cs state edu Kanpur Kanpur UP India satya dev se it ac in Syracuse University Syracuse New York royer ec syr edu Abstract Resource bounded measure is generalization of classical Le be gue measure that is useful in computational complexity The central parameter of resource bounded measure is the resource bound which is class of functions When is unrestricted contains all functions with the specie domains and codomain resource bounded measure coincides with classical Le be gue measure On the other hand when contains functions satisfying some complexity constraint resource bounded measure imposes internal measure structure on corresponding complexity class Most applications of resource bounded measure use only the measure zero measure one fragment of the theory For this fragment can be taken to be class of type one functions from strings to rationals However in the full theory of resource bounded me sur ability and measure the resource bound also contains type two functional To date both the full theory and its zero one fragment have been developed in terms of list of example resource bounds chosen for their apparent utility This paper replaces this list of examples approach with careful investigation of the conditions that su ce for class to be resource bound Our main theorem says that every class that has the closure properties of Me hl horns basic feasible functional is resource bound for measure We also prove that the type versions of the time and space hierarchies that have been extensively used in resource bounded measure have these closure properties In the course of doing this we prove theorems establishing that these time and space resource bounds are all robust Keywords basic feasible functional computational complexity resource bounded measure type two fun tion als

graphical theory of competition on spatial resource gradients Alexei Rya ov and Bernd Blas ius ICBM University of Oldenburg Oldenburg Germany Resource competition is fundamental interaction in natural communities However little is known about competition in spatial environments where organisms are able to regulate resource distributions Here we analyze the competition of two consumers for two resources in one dimensional habitat in which the resources are supplied from opposite sides We show that the success of an invading species crucially depends on the slope of the resource gradients shaped by the resident Our analysis reveals that parameter combinations which lead to coexistence in uniform environment may favor alternative stable states in spatial system and vice versa Furthermore dieren ces in growth rate mortality or dispersal abilities allow consumer to coexist station ari ly with or even out compete competitor with lower resource requirements Applying our theory to phytoplankton model we explain shifts in the community structure that are induced by environmental changes Keywords competition coexistence limiting re it can be created by biotic interactions as local re sources spatial system meta ecosystem invasion anal source consumption can modify resource levels over larger ys is ranges Huston De Angelis possibly establish Correspondence email rya ov icbm de ing resource gradients over the full extent of the habitat blas ius icbm de The analysis of competition in such systems is ma the Ecology Letters mati call challenging Grover as not only the re source availability but also the size of favorable areas Sk ella dispersal rates Abrams Wilson

Energy and environmental aspects of mobile communication systems Lu brit to Petra glia Ve trom ilea Cur cur to Logo rel lib Marsi cob Onofrio Second University of Naples Department of Environmental Science Via Vivaldi Caserta Italy Institute for the Environmental Research Via Bran cat Rome Italy Corresponding author Tel mail address antonio petra glia un in it Petra glia keywords energy consumption telecommunication environmental monitoring sustainable development Published in Energy Volume Issue February Pages Abstract The reduction of the energy consumption of Telecommunication Power System represents one of the critical factors of the telecommunication technologies both to allow sizeable saving of economic resources and to realize sustainable development actions The consumption of about one hundred base stations for mobile phones were monitored for total of over one thousand days in order to study the energy consumption in relation to the environmental electric and logistics parameters of the stations themselves It was possible to survey then the role of the mobile communication systems in the general national energy framework and to plot the best areas of intervention for saving energy and improving the environmental impact showing the role played by air conditioning and transmission equipments Finally new transmission algorithms and the use of renewable energy based techniques have been tested

Communication Systems for Grid Integration of Renewable Energy Resources Richard Yu Peng Zhang Wei dong Xiao and Paul Ch oudh ury Department of Systems and Computer Engineering Carleton University Ottawa ON Canada Email Richard Yu Carleton ca Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering University of Connecticut torr Connecticut USA Email peng en gr uconn edu Program of Electrical Power Engineering Mas dar Institute of Science and Technology Abu Dhabi UAE Email mw xiao mas dar ac Asset Risk Performance Management Department BC Hydro Vancouver BC Canada Email Paul Ch oudh ury bc hydro com Abstract There is growing interest in renewable energy around the world Since most renewable sources are intermittent in nature it is challenging task to integrate renewable energy resources into the power grid infrastructure In this grid integration communication systems are crucial technologies which enable the accommodation of distributed renewable energy generation and play extremely important role in monitoring operating and protecting both renewable energy generators and power systems In this paper we review some communication technologies available for grid integration of renewable energy resources Then we present the communication systems used in real renewable energy project Bear Mountain Wind Farm BMW in British Columbia Canada In addition we present the communication systems used in Photovoltaic Power Systems PP Finally we outline some research challenges and possible solutions about the communication systems for grid integration of renewable energy resources Keywords Communication Systems Grid Renewable Energy

WATER RESOURCES RESEARCH VOL XXXX DOI Transient Water Age Distributions in Environmental Flow Systems The Time Marching Laplace Transform Solution Technique Corn at on Abstract Environmental id circulations are very often characterized by analyzing the fate and behavior of natural and anthropogenic tracers Among these tracers age is taken as an ideal tracer which can yield interesting diagnoses as for example the char act eri ation of the mixing and renewal of water masses of the fate and mixing of con tam in ants or the calibration of hydro is per sive parameters used by numerical models Such diagnoses are of great interest in atmospheric and ocean circulation sciences as well in surface and subsurface hydrology The temporal evolution of groundwater age and its frequency distributions can display important changes as ow regimes vary due to nat ural change in climate and hydro logic conditions and or human induced pressures on the resource to satisfy the water demand Groundwater age being nowadays frequently used to investigate reservoir properties and recharge conditions special attention needs to be put on the way this property is characterized would it be using isotopic methods or math em at ical modelling Steady state age frequency distributions can be modelled using stan dard numerical techniques since the general balance equation describing age transport under steady state ow conditions is exactly equivalent to standard advection dispersion equation The time dependent problem is however described by an extended transport operator that incorporates an additional coordinate for water age The consequence is that numerical solutions can hardly be achieved especially for real applications over large time periods of interest novel algorithm for solving the age distribution pro lem under time varying ow regimes is presented and for some spec ic cong rations extended to the problem of generalized component exposure time The algorithm com bin es the Laplace Transform technique applied to the age or exposure time coordinate with standard time marching schemes The method is validated and illustrated using an aly ical and numerical solutions considering and theoretical groundwater ow domains

Limits on the Be nets of Energy Storage for Renewable Integration Han Su Department of Electrical Engineering Stanford University Stanford CA han is stanford edu Abbas El Gamal Department of Electrical Engineering Stanford University Stanford CA abbas ee stanford edu The high variability of renewable energy resources presents sign cant challenges to the operation of the electric power grid Conventional generators can be used to mitigate this variability but are costly to operate and produce carbon emissions Energy storage provides more environmentally friendly alternative but is costly to deploy in large amounts This paper studies the limits on the be nets of energy storage to renewable energy How eec ti ve is storage at mitigating the adverse eec ts of renewable energy variability How much storage is needed What are the optimal control policies for operating storage To provide answers to these questions we rst formulate the power ow in single bus power system with storage as an in nite horizon stochastic program Wend the optimal policies for arbitrary net renewable generation process when the cost function is the average conventional generation environmental cost and when it is the average loss of load probability reliability cost We obtain more re ned results by considering the multi timescale operation of the power system We view the power ow in each timescale as the superposition of predicted deterministic component and an prediction error residual component and formulate the residual power ow problem as an in nite horizon dynamic program Assuming that the net generation prediction error is an II process we quantify the asymptotic be nets of storage With the additional assumption of Laplace distributed prediction error we obtain closed form expressions for the stationary distribution of storage and conventional generation Finally we propose two threshold policy that trades conventional generation saving with loss of load probability We illustrate our results and corroborate the II and Laplace assumptions numerically using datasets from CAI SO and NREL Key words energy storage renewable integration dynamic programming

Journal of Art ici al Intelligence Research Submitted published Resource Allocation Among Agents with DP Induced Preferences Dmitri Dol gov dol gov stanford edu Technical Research Department Robotics Group Toyota Technical Center Green Road Ann Arbor MI USA Edmund Dur fee dur fee umich edu Electrical Engineering and Computer Science University of Michigan Hayward St Ann Arbor MI USA Abstract Allocating scarce resources among agents to maximize global utility is in general com put ation ally challenging We focus on problems where resources enable agents to execute actions in stochastic environments modeled as Markov decision processes DPs such that the value of resource bundle is de ned as the expected value of the optimal DP policy realizable given these resources We present an algorithm that simultaneously solves the resource allocation and the policy optimization problems This allows us to avoid ex licit ly representing utilities over exponentially many resource bundles leading to drastic often exponential reductions in computational complexity We then use this algorithm in the context of self interested agents to design combinatorial auction for allocating re sources We empirically demonstrate the eec ti ve ness of our approach by showing that it can in minutes optimal ly solve problems for which straightforward combinatorial resource allocation technique would require the agents to enumerate up to resource bundles and the auctioneer to solve an NP complete problem with an input of that size
